titleInfo.title: Cryo-EM Structure and Homology Model of Drosophila Flight Muscle Thick Filaments

mods:mods.abstract: Physicist and Nobel laureate Richard Feynman once famously said, "It is very easy to answer many fundamental biological questions; you just look at the thing!" [8]. Researchers have been trying for years to develop appropriate methods to be able to look at biological specimens and determine their structure in near-atomic resolution. Currently, the major methods available for structure determination of different macromolecular complexes are X-ray crystallography, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), and electron microscopy. For decades X-ray crystallography has been the primary method for protein structure determination, especially to gain high-resolution information about a specimen. There are, however, challenges facing this method as many proteins and macro molecular complexes cannot be crystallized. Filaments are particularly problematic because they cannot be crystallized, and solving the structure by X-ray fiber diffraction is slow and tedious. Also, many proteins have different conformations as they form a crystal compared to their native state. Nuclear magnetic resonance provides novel information about the dynamics of the complex, but it is limited to smaller proteins in size for structure determination. Cryo-EM, on the other hand, introduces a unique opportunity to observe different proteins and macro- molecules in their native state. Muscle structure and function have been studied for decades, with electron microscopy being fundamental in its study by enabling direct observation of proteins without crystallizing them. Now, due to advancements in electron microscopy, we are able to solve the structure of myosin filaments at sub-nanometer resolution for the first time. High-resolution 3D structures of myosin filaments are very important but also very challenging to obtain. 3D structure of the myosin filaments is essential in understanding muscle function and disease. Cryo-EM has proven to be an excellent tool to study myosin molecules since they are 1.6 um in length, form filaments and do not crystallize easily. X-ray diffraction studies along with sequence analysis have shown myosin rods that make up the myosin filaments to be long Î±-helical coiled-coils, a few crystal structures of short myosin segments have also been published. Now, we are able to resolve the sub-nanometer structure of Drosophila thick filaments for the first time and see how the myosin rods pack together to form filaments.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Physics in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.

Kenneth Taylor, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Nicholas Bonesteel, Professor Co-Directing Dissertation; Scott Stagg, University Representative; Paul Cottle, Committee Member; David Van Winkle, Committee Member.
